Daniel Akst may think that home values will continue strengthening (''In Long Run, Residential Real Estate May Beat Stocks,'' On the Contrary, May 5). But as a real estate developer who stopped building two years ago because of concerns about the market (clearly a bit early), I would point out some problems:
* Real estate does not always go up in value. The positive forces affecting it now were in play in the early 90's when the entire industry almost went under.
* You have to feed real estate -- by making mortgage payments and paying taxes, maintenance and utilities. Stock, by contrast, can just sit there until things come around.
* Rental real estate is an interest rate play. Just a few percentage points change it from profit to loss.
* Real estate is illiquid in a down market -- not because of the paperwork, but because nobody wants it.
* Information on real estate is out of date. Everyone watches sales figures, but between sale and occupancy, the entire world can change.

* There is not one kind of real estate. Big units, small units, this side of town, that side of town -- there are a thousand different markets dictated by a hundred different forces. The lovely lakeside recreational property next to ours sat empty and unsold for 12 years.

If you are certain interest rates will always be low and that the economy will always be strong, have lots of disposable income to support empty units, have a complete grasp of demographics and are certain about the effects of global warming and where the next earthquake will be, only then is real estate for you.
